titlestmt.author: Manuscript, Archives, and Rare Book Library, Emory University

address.addressline: Manuscript, Archives, and Rare Book Library

did.physdesc: 40 linear ft.(81 boxes) and 14 oversized papers (OP)
did.abstract: Personal and literary papers of Irish poet Michael Longley consisting of manuscripts, correspondence, printed material, photographs, and records relating to the Arts Council of Nothern Ireland. Also includes some materials relating to literary critic Edna Longley.
did.repository: Emory UniversityManuscript, Archives, and Rare Book Library

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on access
accessrestrict.p: Special restrictions apply: Series 1, Correspondence, letters by Seamus Heaney are closed to researchers.

userestrict.head: Terms Governing Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: All requests subject to limitations noted in departmental policies on reproduction.

prefercite.head: Citation
prefercite.p: [after identification of item(s)], Michael Longley papers, Manuscript, Archives, and Rare Book Library, Emory University.

otherfindaid.head: Finding Aid Note
otherfindaid.p: Index to selected correspondents in Series 1 is available for letters up to 1992.

processinfo.head: Processing
processinfo.p: Processed by Gavin Drummond, Delmas Fellow, 2001

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Michael Longley was born in Belfast, Northern Ireland, on July 27, 1939. He attended Malone Primary School and the Royal Belfast Academical Institution, before going on to Trinity College, Dublin, where he read Classics. After graduating with honors in 1963, he held a variety of teaching positions in Blackrock, Dublin, London, and Belfast.

It was while teaching in Belfast that Longley first attended Philip Hobsbaum's informal gatherings of writers known simply as "the group." There he and other young writers-including Seamus Heaney, Arthur Terry, Jack Packenham, Harry Chambers-read their poems and short stories and helped to foster the work of a new generation of Irish writers.

Longley published his first collection of poems, Ten Poems, in 1966, followed by Three Regional Voices (1967), Room to Rhyme (with Seamus Heaney and David Hammond, 1968), and Secret Marriages (1968). His first major collection of poems, No Continuing City: Poems 1963-1968, was published in 1969 by Macmillan. Since the 1960's Michael Longley has published numerous collections of poems, among them An Exploded View (1973), Man Lying on the Wall (1976), The Echo Gate (1979), Gorse Fires (1991) and The Ghost Orchid (1995). His Selected Poems, 1963 - 1980 was published in 1981, followed by a later selected edition, Poems, 1963 - 1983 in 1985. After his poetic silence of the 1980s, he published Gorse Fires in 1991 to critical acclaim, followed by The Ghost Orchid (1995), Selected Poems (1998), and The Weather in Japan (2000).

Michael Longley has received numerous awards for his poetry including the Eric Gregory Award in 1965 and, more recently, the 1991 Whitbread Poetry Prize for Gorse Fires as well as the 2000 T.S. Eliot Prize for The Weather in Japan. He was awarded the Queen's Gold Medal for poetry in 2001. He is a member of the Royal Society of Literature and of Aosd√°na.

In addition to writing poetry, Longley has also edited collections of poems by Louis MacNeice and W.R. Rodgers, and from 1970 - 1991 he directed the literature programs of the Arts Council of Northern Ireland. In 1994 Longley published a collection of autobiographical prose pieces under the title Tuppenny Stung.
He is married to the critic Edna Longley and lives in Belfast.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of personal and literary papers of Michael Longley from 1960-2000. The bulk of the collection contains drafts, typescripts, and proofs of Longley's poems, essays, and prose pieces and works of other authors, most notably Seamus Heaney and Derek Mahon. The collection also contains correspondence, radio and film scripts, printed material, financial records, records relating to Longley's work for the Arts Council of Northern Ireland, and papers of his wife, Edna Longley.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into nine series: (1) Correspondence, (2) Writings by Michael Longley, (3) Writings by others, (4) Printed material, (5) Photographs, (6) Financial records, (7) Miscellaneous personal files, (8) Belfast Group sheets, (9) Arts Council of Northern Ireland records, (10) Subject files, and (11) Edna Longley papers.

separatedmaterial.head: Related Materials in This Repository
separatedmaterial.p: Seamus Heaney papers, Medbh McGuckian papers, Derek Mahon papers and Paul Muldoon papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The correspondence series of the Michael Longley papers includes letters, telegrams, postcards, and greeting cards both to and from Michael Longley. The earliest items date from 1960, the most recent from 2000. The bulk of the correspondence here is personal or relates to his career as a writer; for correspondence stemming from his career at the Northern Ireland Arts Council, see Series 9. Among the correspondents represented in this series are: Fleur Adcock, Eavan Boland, Ciaran Carson, Douglas Dunn, Gavin Ewart, Peter Fallon, Brian Friel, Seamus Heaney, Philip Hobsbaum, Jennifer Johnston, Medbh McGuckian, Derek Mahon, John Montague, Paul Muldoon, Frank Ormsby, Craig Raine, James Simmons, and Anthony Thwaite. Occasionally Michael Longley's own letters (most often in carbon or in draft form) are also present.

The correspondence within this series is arranged chronologically, when a date is known. When an item is undated, or when a date is illegible, postmarks have been used to place the item. Those items for which only a month or year is known will be found at the end of the month's or year's sequence, while those items without any indication of date whatsoever are filed at the very end of the chronological arrangement. Undated letters from indexed correspondents are filed alphabetically by writer's name in Box 13. Among these letters is an extensive correspondence with Derek Mahon.

otherfindaid.head: Finding Aid Note
otherfindaid.p: Index to selected correspondents in Series 1 is available for letters up to 1992.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on access
accessrestrict.p: Special restrictions apply: Letters by Seamus Heaney are closed to researchers.

did.unittitle: Undated indexed correspondence, Adcock - McGuckian [Fleur Adcock, Eavan Boland, Ciaron Carson, Paul Durcan, Brian Friel, Puller Grimes, Donald Hall, Philip Hobsbaum, Johnstone, McGuckian]
Undated indexed correspondence, Montague - Trevor [John Montague, Paul Muldoon, Nuala ni Dhomhnaill, Frank Ormsby, Craig Raine, James Simmons, William Trevor]
Restricted 20 years from April 2004, per SH review

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The largest portion of the Michael Longley papers is made up of Michael Longley's own writings. This portion of the collection is divided into seven subseries: poetry by Michael Longley, where individual poems are organized by major volume in which they first appeared, and proofs of complete volumes are also included; prose writings; radio and film scripts; works edited by Michael Longley; interviews with Michael Longley; fragments and notes; notebooks.

The first subseries contains material directly linked to his published collections, drafts of uncollected poems, unpublished / proposed groupings of poems, and unidentified manuscripts. Materials relating to his published collections may include drafts of the book's table of contents, individual poems, complete typescripts, or proofs. The manuscripts of individual poems have been arranged alphabetically by the poem's title. If a poem was known by more than one title, the variant title(s) have been provided in brackets. If a poem was made up of, or included, other poems this is also indicated in brackets, thus [includes . . . .]. Cross-references are used for those poems that may have manuscript material under more than one title. Drafts are both manuscripts (MS) and typescripts (TS) unless otherwise noted.

The second subseries is made up of an alphabetical arrangement of Michael Longley's prose writings; essays and reviews by Longley are present as well as lecture notes and notes from public readings of his work. Unidentified poems and prose pieces follow their respective subseries.

Subseries 2.3 consists primarily of the scripts written by Michael Longley, unless otherwise indicated in brackets, such as [reader] or [conversation with . . . ]. Such scripts not necessarily written by Longley but which involve him centrally are included here. Works edited by Longley can be found in Subseries 2.4. Subseries 2.5 contains interviews with Michael Longley, mostly in typescript form, often annotated either by the interviewer or Michael Longley. If the interview was published, details are added in brackets.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into six subseries: (2.1) Poems, (2.2) Prose, (2.3) Radio and film scripts, (2.4) Works edited by Michael Longley, (2.5) Interviews, and (2.6) Notebooks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Michael Longley papers include numerous poems and prose works in manuscript or typescript form by other contemporary writers. Particularly well-represented are both Seamus Heaney and Derek Mahon. When a manuscript was included as an enclosure with a letter, it has been filed with that letter in Series 1. See also Series 8, Belfast Group sheets.
Subseries 3.3 includes prose works and drama, as well as radio scripts, screenplays, and some artwork.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: (3.1) Poetry, (3.2) Essays on Michael Longley, and (3.3) Other writings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Series 4 includes assorted printed material, including clippings, reviews, and promotional material for Michael Longley's own books and readings. Subseries 4.1 consists of printed material by Longley. Most are poems unless otherwise marked in brackets.
Subseries 4.2 contains reviews and promotional material concerning Longley's writings, as well as newspaper clippings which mention Longley, and longer pieces which involve the writer more centrally.

The bulk of Subseries 4.3 has been divided into three main categories: printed material with a literary subject, printed material concerning the Arts (particularly painting), and any other printed material.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: (4.1) Printed material by Michael Longley, (4.2) Printed material about Michael Longley, and (4.3) General printed material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series contains photographs of Michael Longley, spanning most of his life, although the bulk of the images are from the mid-1980s onwards. There are a few photos of Longley with other literary figures, as well as pictures of various members of his family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: In the early 1960s, the poet Philip Hobsbaum founded in Belfast an informal writers' group where the participants could read and discuss each other's work. Poems and, in some cases, short stories that were being presented at these meetings were customarily mimeographed and distributed to those attending. These "group sheets" make up a distinct series, and include early work by Seamus Heaney, Derek Mahon, Paul Muldoon, and Michael Longley, among others.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Collections in this Repository
relatedmaterial.p: Belfast Group sheets may also be found in the Irish Literary Miscellany.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Arranged in alphabetical order by author.

Arts Council of Northern Ireland records, 1969-1991

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Michael Longley worked for the Arts Council of Northern Ireland (ACNI) from 1970 - 1991. Initially employed as temporary Exhibitions Officer, he quickly became director of Traditional Arts; in 1982 he became Combined Arts Director, a position from which he oversaw Traditional Arts, Young Arts and Community Arts. Throughout his career with the Arts Council he was particularly interested in encouraging literature in Northern Ireland, although as his autobiographical essay "Blackthorn & Bonsai" shows, he often did so in the face of much resistance from the Council. Towards the end of his tenure with ACNI he also became a founder member of the Cultural Traditions Group, an organization which attempted to celebrate the diverse traditions of the Irish arts scene. This series contains correspondence and printed material relating to all of these matters. Particularly notable here is correspondence from numerous publishing organizations, including publishing houses and "little" magazines, showing the burgeoning of literary output during the 1970s and 1980s in Ireland.

Subseries 9.1 contains materials collected by Michael Longley in connection with the Arts Council of Northern Ireland (ACNI). These materials pertain to the Council as a whole, as distinct from a particular department. It includes reports made by Longley to the Council, as well as various Council minutes, reports, agendas and new releases.

Subseries 9.2 features various types of materials pertaining to specific ACNI Projects in the areas of Literature, Traditional Arts, Community Arts, and Young Arts. The correspondence subseries (9.3) has been divided into two main categories: correspondence regarding literary subjects, and correspondence regarding traditional Irish arts and community. The Literature category has been further divided into subcategories based on correspondent: correspondence with magazines and journals, presses, organizations, educational institutions, libraries, theatres and individuals. Arts Council publications, newspaper clippings, and other various printed material comprise Subseries 9.4.

During his tenure as an Arts Council director, Michael Longley also became a member of the Cultural Traditions Group, which was established in 1988. A branch of Northern Ireland's Community Relations Council, the Cultural Traditions Group promoted traditional Irish culture and art-much like ACNI's Traditional Arts department. Subseries 9.5 features materials that relate to the Cultural Traditions Group: correspondence, minutes, and printed material. [Note: Cultural Traditions Group has since been renamed "Cultural Diversity Programme."]

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into five subseries: (9.1) General Arts Council materials, (9.2) Arts Council projects, (9.3) Correspondence, (9.4) Printed material, and (9.5) Cultural Traditions Group materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Series 10 groups together various printed materials which have an integrity as grouped entities. Such subject files tend to concern particular visits Michael Longley made to other countries, usually on reading tours; however other kinds of subject are represented here, such as the Charabanc Theatre Company, on which Michael Longley served as a member of the governing board, as well as a file for Seaman James Magennis, who inspired the poem "Ocean."

Miscellaneous resumes, and recommendations written by Michael Longley

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Michael Longley collection contains a good deal of material by or about his wife, Edna Longley. Edna Longley is an eminent academic and critic who has taught for many years at Queen's University, Belfast. Collections of her criticism, including Poetry Between the Wars (1986), The Living Stream (1994) and Poetry and Posterity (2000), are some of the most important interventions in contemporary Irish poetry criticism. The series is divided into two distinct sections. The first contains materials more squarely concerning Edna Longley's academic life, including correspondence 1962-2000 and a number of drafts and typescripts of lectures and essays. The second contains materials concerning the John Hewitt Summer School (JHSS), and particularly documents regarding her acrimonious departure from the board of the JHSS in 1996.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: (11.1) Edna Longley materials and (11.2) John Hewitt Summer School records.
